title: What Sims will find when he delves into bank pricing
text:
In its 2019 half-year results, Westpac said that its NIM (excluding Treasury & Markets) had declined 12 basis points from the same period in 2018 "due to provisions for customer refunds and higher short-term funding costs".

The bank said that the bank's net interest margin of 2.12 per cent in the first half of 2019 was down 4 basis points from the second half of 2018.

"Notable items which reflect additional provisions for estimated customer refunds and payments (mostly in Consumer and Business Bank) reduced margin by a net 3 basis points in the half," the bank said.

Tighter margins

Analysts said Westpac's NIM was likely impacted by the refunds that the bank was forced to make to those customers who weren't notified that they could switch from their interest-only loans to principal and interest loans.

The corporate regulator forced the Sydney-based bank to refund customers the amount they could have saved had they chosen to start paying down the amount outstanding on their loans.

National Australia Bank also reported a lower NIM in its latest half yearly result as a result of customer remediation costs.

Advertisement

In its half-year results, released in May, the Melbourne-based bank said that its group net interest margin fell from 1.84 per cent last September to 1.79 per cent in March, a drop of 5 basis points.

According to the NAB, tighter lending margins accounted for 3 basis points of this decline in NIM. "Customer-related remediation" – essentially the repayment of interest to customers – wiped a further 1 basis point off the bank's NIM.

However, not all the banks are suffering a squeeze on their NIMs as a result of customer remediation.

According to ANZ, its NIM fell from 1.82 per cent in the second half of 2018 to 1.80 per cent in the first half of 2019.

But this drop largely reflected the effect of holding more liquid assets on the balance sheet, which pushed the NIM down by 4 basis points. In contrast, customer remediation boosted the bank's NIM by 2 basis points, as these fell in the first half of 2019 compared with the previous six months.

Sims will also discover the somewhat bemusing fact that not all the major banks include aspects of customer remediation in their NIMs.

In its results for the year to June 2019, the Commonwealth Bank said that its NIM held steady in the first six months of this year from the previous six months at 2.10 per cent. But the giant bank's operating expenses – which included close to $1 billion in remediation costs – were up by 2.5 per cent.

And CBA boss Matt Comyn signalled that the Reserve Bank's rate cuts in June and July would reduce the bank's NIM by around 4 basis points in the 2020 financial year.
description: ACCC boss Rod Sims will need to become nimble with NIMs as he investigates allegations the banks are shortchanging their loyal customers on interest rates.
